summary: This 1930 West African Court of Appeal decision involved an application for conditional leave to appeal to the Privy Council. The judgment awarded the plaintiffs-respondents a sum of £491 5s. 6d., which included interest. The appellant contended that costs should be included to exceed the £500 appeal threshold. The court rejected this, citing precedent that costs cannot be counted toward the appealable amount when the substantive judgment is below the threshold, as established in Doorga Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry and Great Western Ry. of Canada v. Braid. The application was dismissed with costs.

judges.name: Young
judges.role: Acting Chief Justice of Sierra Leone

citations: Doorga Chowdry v. Ramanauth Chowdry 8 Moo. 3rd app. 262
Great Western Ry. of Canada v. Braid, 1 Moo. P.C. (N.S.) 101
rationaleHighlights: Costs cannot be included to meet the appeal threshold if the judgment amount is below the required value.
Precedent clearly establishes that only the substantive judgment, not costs, counts toward the appealable amount.
Interest was included in the judgment but did not raise the principal to the threshold.
Application dismissed without requiring response from respondents due to lack of legal merit.
confidenceNotes: High confidence; information directly extracted from judgment text and consistent with legal principles of the period.
